Meeting: June 19, 2023
File: 49500 20 REZ 21-30
Council Report to: Mayor & Council
From: General Manager Planning and Development
Subject: REZ #21-30 - Portion of 2160 Springer Avenue, 2210 Springer Avenue, and Portion of 5334 Lougheed Highway - Bassano Master Plan Phase 1 - Brentwood Town Centre Development Plan
Purpose: Seek Council authorization to forward application to future Public Hearing date
Recommendations:
1. Prepare and advance Rezoning Bylaw to First Reading and Public Hearing at a future date.
2. Approve amendment to Brentwood Town Centre Development Plan.
3. Authorize introduction of Highway Closure Bylaw.
4. Approve sale of City-owned property for inclusion in development site.
5. Establish prerequisites for completion of rezoning.
Chief Administrative Officer's Comments: Concur with General Manager Planning and Development's recommendation.
Executive Summary: Rezoning application received for Phase 1 of Bassano Site Master Plan. Recommend forwarding to future Public Hearing.
Policy Section: Proposed rezoning consistent with various policies and plans adopted by Council.
Background: On July 25, 2022, Council granted Final Adoption to Rezoning Reference #17-14 for Bassano Site Conceptual Master Plan.
Development includes street-fronting townhouses. The subject site is Phase 1 of the three-phased Master Plan.

On October 04, 2021, Council approved a report endorsing a density and rental obligation transfer between the subject site and 5650 Beresford Street (Beresford Site), owned by the applicant. This transfer aims to create a fully non-market rental project at the Beresford Site. The Beresford Site will initially serve as rental housing for displaced tenants from development sites within the Metrotown Downtown Plan Area and beyond. These tenants will be relocated while their replacement rental unit is being constructed. The rental units will be delivered before or at the same time as Phase 1 of the Bassano Site. These units will fulfill the inclusionary rental requirement for Phases 1 and 2 of the Bassano Site, as well as the inclusionary requirement for the Beresford Site. Displaced residents from other developments can temporarily reside at the Beresford Site until their new unit is ready. Tenants will only be responsible for the portion of rent equivalent to their rent at the time of rezoning, with the developer paying any additional rent. Once Phase 3 of the Bassano Site is completed, the required rental units at the Beresford Site will revert to standard inclusionary rental rates, set at 20% below CMHC median market rates for the Southeast Burnaby rental survey area. Phase 3 of the Bassano Site will include a non-market rental podium to meet the overall inclusionary rental requirement for both the Bassano and Beresford Sites. Additional voluntary rental units at the Beresford or Bassano Site, utilizing RMr density, can be a mix of market and non-market rental units on a 1:1 basis as permitted under the Rental Use Zoning Policy. A density transfer between the two sites is proposed to facilitate this. Further details on the proposed swing site concept can be found in the Beresford Site rezoning report (Rezoning Reference #21-29), which is also on Council's agenda.

Establish prerequisites to the completion of the rezoning, including the submission of a suitable plan of development, deposit of sufficient monies, installation of necessary services, undergrounding of wiring, removal of existing improvements, completion of Rezoning Reference #21-30, consolidation of the net project site, completion of the Highway Closure Bylaw and sale of City property, dedication of rights-of-way, granting of necessary statutory rights-of-way, easements, and/or covenants, registration of a Housing Covenant and Housing Agreement, submission of a suitable on-site Stormwater Management System, compliance with Groundwater Management guidelines, submission of a Solid Waste and Recycling Plan, review of on-site loading facilities, provision of facilities for cyclists, design and provision of units adaptable to persons with disabilities, compliance with sound criteria, compliance with guidelines for underground parking for visitors, submission of a Green Building Plan and Energy Benchmarking, submission of a Site Disclosure Statement and resolution of any resultant conditions, deposit of applicable charges (Parkland Acquisition Charge, School Site Acquisition Charge, GVS & DD Sewerage Charge, Regional Water Cost Charge, Regional Transportation Development Cost Charge).
Chief Administrative Officer’s Comments: I concur with the recommendation of the General Manager Planning and Development.
Executive Summary: A rezoning application has been received for the construction of a six-storey purpose built residential rental building. The purpose of this report is to provide Council with information on the proposal and recommend forwarding the rezoning application to a future Public Hearing.
Policy Section: The proposed rezoning application is consistent with various policies and plans adopted by Council.
Background: On October 04, 2021, Council approved a report seeking endorsement of a density and rental obligation transfer between the subject site (Beresford Site) and the Bassano Master Plan Site, owned by the applicant, in order to deliver a fully non-market rental project.
The subject site will initially serve as rental housing for displaced tenants from development sites within the Metrotown Downtown Plan Area and beyond. The rental units will be delivered prior to or concurrently with Phase 1 of the Bassano Site. These units will satisfy the inclusionary rental requirement for Phases 1 and 2 of the Bassano Site, as well as the inclusionary requirement for the subject site. Displaced residents from other rental developments can be housed at the subject site until their unit in their new development is ready. Tenants will only be responsible for the portion of the rent equivalent to their rent at the time of rezoning, with the developer paying any applicable rent top-up. After Phase 3 of the Bassano Site is completed, the subject site's required rental units will revert to standard inclusionary rental rates, set at 20% below CMHC median market rates for the Southeast Burnaby rental survey area. Phase 3 of the Bassano Site will include a non-market rental podium to meet the overall inclusionary rental requirement for both sites. Additional voluntary rental units at the subject site or Bassano Site can be provided as a mix of market and non-market rental units on a 1:1 basis. A density transfer between the two sites is proposed to facilitate this. Further details on the swing site concept and density transfer can be found in Sections 3.2 and 3.3 of this report. The Phase 1 Bassano Site rezoning report also appears on Council's agenda.

PURPOSE: To inform Council of an expanded site proposed for Rezoning Reference (REZ) #19-07.
REFERENCES
Address: 4330 Kingsway and 4370 Kingsway
Legal: Lot 1 District Lot 153 Group 1 New Westminster District Plan EPP107270; and Lot 1 District Lot 153 Group 1 New Westminster District Plan 68123
Applicant: Steven Dejonckheere; Screo I Metrotown Inc.
Current Zoning: CD Comprehensive Development District (based on C3 General Commercial District)
Proposed Zoning: CD Comprehensive Development District (based on RM5s/RM5r Multiple-Family Residential District, C3 General Commercial District, and Metrotown Downtown Plan as guidelines)
RECOMMENDATION
THAT the Planning and Development Department be authorized to continue to work with the applicant for REZ #19-07 towards a revised plan of development on the expanded site, based on an amended CD Comprehensive Development District (using the RM5s and RM5r Multiple Family Residential Districts, and the C3 General Commercial District as guidelines).
CHIEF ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICER’S COMMENTS
I concur with the recommendation of the General Manager Planning and Development.
1.0 POLICY SECTION
The proposed rezoning application is consistent with the following policies and plans adopted by Council:
• Corporate Strategic Plan (2022)
• Regional Context Statement (2013)
• Official Community Plan (1998)
• Metrotown Downtown Plan (2017)
• Economic Development Strategy (2007)
• Social Sustainability Strategy (2011)
• Environmental Sustainability Strategy (2016)
• Transportation Plan (2021)
• HOME: Housing and Homelessness Strategy (2021)
Subject: REZ #19-07 - 4330 Kingsway – Expanded Site Proposal
Open Council Meeting June 19, 2023
Page 2
• Rental Use Zoning Policy (2020).
2.0 BACKGROUND
On April 29, 2019, Council authorized staff to work with the applicant to create a suitable plan of development for the site located at 4330 Kingsway and 5945 Kathleen (REZ #19-07). Thereafter, these two parcels were consolidated and are now referred to together as 4330 Kingsway (see attached Sketch #1).
The initial purpose of the rezoning application was to rezone the consolidated site at 4330 Kingsway to the amended CD Comprehensive Development District (using the C3 General Commercial District as a guideline), in order to permit the renovation of the two existing commercial office buildings on the site. The proposed renovations include the recladding of the two office buildings and alterations to the site’s public realm and landscaping, as well as the addition of floor area with the intent of improving the street presence of the buildings. It is noted that 4370 Kingsway, improved with a two-storey commercial building occupied by a bank on the southwest corner of Kingsway and Kathleen Avenue, was not included as part of the subject rezoning application, although existing legal arrangements related to shared parking, loading, and access with the subject site were secured.
Although the proposal did not align with the site’s high-density mixed-use designation under the Metrotown Downtown Plan, the rezoning advanced through a Public Hearing and received Second and Third Reading from Council on August 24, 2020 and June 28, 2021 respectively, on the basis that the proposal supports the retention of employment opportunities in the Metrotown area.
3.0 GENERAL INFORMATION
The applicant has submitted a revised letter of intent to include the property at 4370 Kingsway, thus expanding the subject site to cover the entire block bounded by Kingsway, Kathleen Avenue, Kemp Street, and Wilson Avenue (see attached Sketch #1). In addition, the applicant intends to revise a portion of the development concept to redevelop the eastern portion of the site in line with the Metrotown Downtown Plan’s, high-density mixed-use development designation under the CD Comprehensive Development District (using the RM5s and RM5r Multiple Family Residential Districts, and the C3 General Commercial District as guidelines).
The revised proposal would replace the existing 10-storey commercial office building at the southeast corner of the site with a high-density mixed-use building comprised of both market and non-market dwelling units, and street-activating retail uses. The revised proposal also includes the replacement of the existing two-storey commercial building at 4370 Kingsway with a future commercial office building. The existing 19-storey commercial office building on the northwest corner of the site will be retained and re-cladded, as originally intended.

Policy Section: Proposed rezoning application consistent with various policies and plans adopted by Council.

Plan identifies neighbourhood as residential "heart" of Metrotown with high-density multiple-family development. On April 27, 2020, Council received a rezoning report for the four properties (6645, 6659, 6675, and 6691 Dow Avenue) in line with the adopted Plan. Council authorized staff to work with the applicant to create a suitable development plan.

On October 25, 2021, Staff provided an expanded site report to Council, informing them of the applicant's intention to revise their original proposal to include the property at 6707 Dow Avenue. This property is designated for high-density multiple family residential development in the adopted Metrotown Downtown Plan. Council authorized staff to continue working with the applicant to develop a plan that includes this additional property.

The proposed development site consists of five lots and follows guidelines from the RM5s, RM5r, RM4s, and RM4r Districts. The maximum permitted density for the redevelopment of the subject site is calculated based on the proportions of the different residential designations on the consolidated site.

The existing rental apartment buildings on the subject properties were built between 1955 and 1964 and have two to three storeys. There are currently 112 rental units across the five sites. Vehicular access to 6645 Dow Avenue is from a rear lane, while access to the other four properties is from Dow Avenue. The proposed CD Comprehensive Development District zoning includes the RM5r and RM4r Multiple Family Residential Districts to support the replacement of existing rental units and meet the City's Rental Use Zoning Policy requirements.

Meeting: June 19, 2023
File: 49500 20 REZ 21-30
Council Report to: Mayor & Council
From: General Manager Planning and Development
Subject: REZ #21-30 - Portion of 2160 Springer Avenue, 2210 Springer Avenue, and Portion of 5334 Lougheed Highway – Bassano Master Plan Phase 1 – Brentwood Town Centre Development Plan
Purpose: To seek Council authorization to forward this application to a future Public Hearing date.
Recommendations:
1. Prepare a Rezoning Bylaw for First Reading and Public Hearing.
2. Approve the amendment to the Brentwood Town Centre Development Plan.
3. Authorize the introduction of a Highway Closure Bylaw.
4. Approve the sale of City-owned property for inclusion within the development site.
5. Establish prerequisites for the completion of the rezoning.
Chief Administrative Officer's Comments: I concur with the recommendation.
Executive Summary: A rezoning application has been received for the construction of Phase 1 of the Bassano Site Master Plan, consisting of a high-rise residential building with retail and underground parking. Recommend forwarding the application to a future Public Hearing.
Policy Section: The proposed rezoning application is consistent with various policies and plans adopted by Council.
Background: On July 25, 2022, Council granted Final Adoption to Rezoning Reference #17-14 for the Bassano Site Conceptual Master Plan. The intent was to guide site-specific rezoning applications for high-density apartment development.
Development, with street-fronting townhouses, comprises Phase 1 of the three-phased Master Plan. On October 04, 2021, Council approved a report endorsing a density and rental obligation transfer between the subject site and 5650 Beresford Street (Beresford Site), owned by the applicant. This transfer aims to deliver a fully non-market rental project at the Beresford Site. The Beresford Site will initially serve as rental housing for displaced tenants from development sites within the Metrotown Downtown Plan Area and beyond, while their replacement rental unit is constructed. The rental units will be delivered prior to or concurrently with Phase 1 of the Bassano Site. These units will satisfy the inclusionary rental requirement for Phases 1 and 2 of the Bassano Site, as well as the inclusionary requirement for the Beresford Site. Displaced residents from other developments can be housed at the Beresford Site until their unit in the new development is ready. Tenants will only be responsible for the portion of the rent equivalent to their rent at the time of rezoning, with the developer paying any applicable rent top-up. After the completion of Phase 3 of the Bassano Site, the Beresford Site's required rental units will revert to the standard inclusionary rental rates, set at 20% below CMHC median market rates for the Southeast Burnaby rental survey area. Phase 3 of the Bassano Site will include a non-market rental podium to meet the overall inclusionary rental requirement for both the Bassano and Beresford Sites. Additional voluntary rental units at the Beresford or Bassano Site, utilizing RMr density, can be provided as a mix of market and non-market rental units on a 1:1 basis as permitted under the Rental Use Zoning Policy. A density transfer between the two sites is proposed to facilitate this. Further details on the proposed swing site concept are outlined in the Beresford Site rezoning report (Rezoning Reference #21-29), which also appears on Council's agenda.

Cana Meeting August 28, 2023
File: 2410-20
COUNCIL REPORT
TO: MAYOR & COUNCIL
FROM: DEPUTY GENERAL MANAGER PARKS, RECREATION AND CULTURE
SUBJECT: 2023 ROYAL CANADIAN MOUNTED POLICE MUSICAL RIDE
PURPOSE: To seek Council approval for a charitable donation from the proceeds of the RCMP Musical Ride at Swangard Stadium on June 26, 2023.
RECOMMENDATION: THAT the donation of proceeds, totaling $10,000 from the RCMP Musical Ride event, be approved to be shared equally between Canadian Cancer Society - Cops for Cancer and Honour House Society.
CHIEF ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICER’S COMMENTS: I concur with the recommendation of the General Manager Parks, Recreation and Culture.
1.0 POLICY SECTION: This event follows the City of Burnaby Social Sustainability strategy and demonstrates Burnaby as a caring, livable community which celebrates creativity and fosters connections to community life.
2.0 BACKGROUND: The year 2023 marks the 150th Anniversary of the RCMP in Canada. In recognition of this milestone, a commemorative cross-Canada RCMP Musical Ride tour was organized and a performance took place at Swangard Stadium on June 26, 2023. The opportunity to host the Musical Ride was particularly meaningful for the community as it provided an opportunity to honour the memory of Constable Yang along with providing support to the local RCMP. The event was a success with approximately 3,700 tickets sold. In addition to the RCMP Musical Ride, the event was emceed by Kevin Lim and featured performances from the RCMP Lower Mainland Intergraded Police Dog Services, the “E” Division, Pipes, Drums and Dancers, Sardis Secondary Drum Line as well as the singing of O Canada by Stephen Scaccia. There were a number of activities for families and many participants opted to stay after the Musical Ride performance to enjoy a beautiful early summer evening at the stadium.
3.0 GENERAL INFORMATION: The charitable donation portion of the RCMP Musical Ride is a requirement as stated in the Memorandum of Understanding signed with the RCMP in order to host the event.
Subject: 2023 Royal Canadian Mounted Police Musical Ride
Open Council Meeting August 28, 2023 ....................................... Page 2
In 2018, the historical charitable donation of $10,000 was evenly split between Canadian Cancer Society - Cops for Cancer and Burnaby KidSport. In 2023, the charitable donation will be shared equally between Canadian Cancer Society – Cops for Cancer and the Honour House Society. The Burnaby RCMP decided on the Honour House Society for their continuing support for First Responders, Canadian Armed Forces personnel and Veterans while the members receive medical care. Specifically, they provided accommodations for the family members of Cst. Shaelyn Yang free of charge and have done so in the past for other family members of fallen officers. As for the Canadian Cancer Society - Cops for Cancer, several representatives from Burnaby Detachment are participating in the Cops for Cancer Tour de Coast Ride this year and the donated funds help support cancer research specifically from the funds raised by the Cops for Cancer.
4.0 COMMUNICATION AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT: The event success is reflected through a sellout crowd and an overall attendance of over 4,500 members of the community. Feedback from the patrons and from riders indicated that Swangard Stadium is an iconic venue to host this event and the highlight of the tour.
5.0 FINANCIAL CONSIDERATIONS: The costs associated with hosting were forecast in January with a net cost to the City of $22,000. As outlined below, due to the event meeting the ticket sale projections and some cost savings including shared stabling and feed costs for horses with the City of Surrey, the net cost to the City will come in at under $7,000.
Item Projected Actual
RCMP Musical Ride Expenses $68,000 $52,476.14

Subject: REZ #22-38 – Brentwood West Phase 1 and 2 – Brentwood Town Centre Development Plan
Purpose: Seek Council authorization to forward the application to a future Public Hearing.
References:
Address: 4430, 4488 Halifax Street, and 1801 Willingdon Avenue
Legal: Lot 2 District Lot 119 Group 1 New Westminster District Plan 81971; Lot 1 District Lot 119 Group 1 New Westminster District Plan BCP29826; and Lot 57 District Lot 119 Group 1 New Westminster District Plan 41060

Proposed Zoning: Amended CD Comprehensive Development District (based on C3 General Commercial District, RM5s Multiple Family Residential District, RM5r Multiple Family Residential District, and Brentwood Town Centre Plan as guidelines and in accordance with the development plan entitled “Proposed Mixed-Use Commercial and Residential Development” prepared by Chris Dikeakos Architects Inc.)
Recommendations:
1. Authorize the introduction of a Housing Agreement Bylaw according to the terms outlined in Sections 3.3 and 3.13 of the report, contingent upon the granting of Second Reading of the Rezoning Bylaw.
2. Authorize the introduction of a Highway Closure Bylaw according to the terms outlined in Section 3.11 of the report, contingent upon the granting of Second Reading of the Rezoning Bylaw.
3. Approve the sale of City-owned property for inclusion within the development site, subject to the terms outlined in Section 3.11 of the report and the applicant pursuing the rezoning proposal to completion.
4. Prepare a Rezoning Bylaw for First Reading and a Public Hearing at a future date.
5. Establish prerequisites for the completion of the rezoning, including the submission of a suitable plan of development, deposit of sufficient monies, installation of necessary services, undergrounding of wiring, removal of existing improvements, utilization of an amenity bonus, completion of the Highway Closure Bylaw and sale of City property, consolidation of the net project site, dedication of rights-of-way, and granting of necessary statutory rights-of-way, easements, and covenants.
Chief Administrative Officer's Comments: Concur with the recommendation of the General Manager Planning and Development.
Executive Summary: A rezoning application has been received for the construction of two high-rise mixed tenure residential apartment buildings atop a commercial podium and underground parking in accordance with Phase 1 and 2 of the Brentwood West Master Plan. Recommend forwarding the rezoning application to a future Public Hearing.
Policy Section: The proposed rezoning application is consistent with various policies and plans adopted by Council.
Background: On July 25, 2022, Council granted Final Adoption to Rezoning Reference #19-19 for the Brentwood West Conceptual Master Plan. The Master Plan aims to guide development of the subject site into a multi-phased, high-density, mixed-use area with housing options, employment opportunities, and public open space provisions. The subject site comprises phases 1 and 2 of the Master Plan.
The subject site is located at the southwest corner of Willingdon Avenue and Halifax Street, within the Council adopted Brentwood Town Centre Development Plan. It is designated for high-density mixed-use development, utilizing the RM5s, RM5r Multiple Family Residential Districts, C3 General Commercial District, and the Brentwood Town Centre Development Plan as guidelines. The site is approximately 7090.08 m2 (76,317 sq. ft.) in size and is comprised of three individual parcels and a portion of Buchanan Street, which is identified for closure under the Brentwood Town Centre Development Plan. Two of the parcels (4430 Halifax Street and 1801 Willingdon Avenue) are currently improved with older commercial buildings, and the remaining parcel at 4488 Halifax Street is vacant.

On 2023 February 06, Council received an initial rezoning report proposing to rezone the subject development site from its prevailing CD Comprehensive Development District to an amended CD Comprehensive Development District utilizing the RM5s Multiple Family Residential District, RM5r Multiple Family Residential District, C3 General Commercial District, and the Brentwood Town Centre Development Plan as guidelines. The applicant has now submitted a plan of development suitable for presentation to a Public Hearing.

The proposed development plan for the subject site includes two high-rise residential apartment buildings atop a non-market residential rental and commercial/retail podium with underground parking. The development will be constructed over two main phases, with Phase 1 encompassing the western half of the site and Phase 2 the eastern half. Phase 1 includes a single 60 storey residential strata apartment building, a 9 storey non-market rental podium with townhouses fronting Buchanan Street, and locally scaled commercial retail units fronting Halifax Street. Phase 1 also includes a shared surface plaza accessed from Buchanan Street and a pedestrianized commercial arcade connecting Halifax Street through to Buchanan Street. Phase 2 includes a single 43 storey mixed-use tower with market rental uses located on the upper floors, office uses in the podium, and locally scaled commercial retail units at the base of the building fronting all bounding streets and public spaces. Phase 2 also includes the closure of a portion of Buchanan Street for consolidation with the development site to enable the realization of a new public square.

- Authorize introduction of Housing Agreement Bylaw according to terms outlined in Sections 3.3 and 3.11 of this report by General Manager of Planning and Development, Rezoning Reference #22-29 dated September 25, 2023, contingent upon granting of Second Reading of subject Rezoning Bylaw by Council
- Establish prerequisites to completion of rezoning, including submission of suitable plan of development, deposit of sufficient monies including 4% Engineering Administration Fee, completion of servicing agreement, installation of electrical, telephone, and cable servicing underground, advancement of Willingdon Lands Master Plan to Final Adoption, subdivision of Phase 1 subject site, dedication of necessary rights-of-way, granting of necessary statutory rights-of-way, easements, and/or covenants, registration of Housing Covenant and Housing Agreement, submission of suitable on-site stormwater management system, deposit of sufficient monies for provision of stormwater management system, submission of Phasing and Construction Management Plan, compliance with City’s Groundwater Management for Multi-Family Development guidelines, submission of Site Disclosure Statement, submission of Tree Management Plan and Arborist report, submission of Solid Waste and Recycling plan, review of on-site residential loading facilities, provision of car wash stalls and garbage handling and recycling material holding space, and commitment to implement recycling provisions.
Executive Summary:
- Rezoning application received for multiple family residential development in Willingdon Lands Urban Village Master Plan Phase 1
- Development consists of three buildings: six-storey non-market rental building, 14-storey market rental and non-market rental building, and 20-storey leasehold strata building with street-oriented townhomes
- Recommend forwarding rezoning application to future Public Hearing
Policy Section:
- Proposed rezoning application consistent with various policies and plans adopted by Council
Background:
- Willingdon Lands site designated as Urban Village and Business Centre in Official Community Plan Amendment Bylaw #14451
- Willingdon Lands Master Plan establishes conceptual plan for mixed-use urban village community
- Rezoning report for Phase 1 of Willingdon Lands Urban Village received, proposing rezoning of subject development site
In accordance with its Urban Village designation under the Official Community Plan and Willingdon Lands Master Plan, Council authorized staff to work with the applicant on a suitable plan of development. The applicant has now submitted a plan of development for presentation at a Public Hearing.

The Willingdon Lands Master Plan originally proposed seven phases of construction. The applicant has proposed to separate the film studio from the residential component of Phase 1 and build it in a subsequent phase. The proposed development plan for Phase 1 includes three multiple family residential buildings with underground parking.

'Midrise 1A' is a six-storey non-market rental building located on the north side of the Phase 1 site. It is rented at 20% below CMHC Market Median rental rates. 'Tower 1B' is a 20-storey leasehold strata building situated at the intersection of Goard Way and Willingdon Avenue. It includes street-oriented townhomes and an outdoor rooftop amenity space. 'Tower 1C' is a 14-storey rental building with a mix of market rental units and non-market rental units. It has both indoor and outdoor amenity space and a green roof terrace.

Vehicular access to the Phase 1 site is from the new east-west road. There are two separate underground parkades and a central servicing courtyard for loading, waste collection, and pick up and drop off.

References:

Legal: Lot 53, DL 4, Group 1, NWDP 31308, Except Reference Plan 34875, Plans LMP52627 and EPP10715

2. Prepare a Rezoning Bylaw and advance it to a Public Hearing at a future date.
3. Establish prerequisites to the completion of the rezoning, including the submission of a suitable plan of development, deposit of sufficient monies for all necessary services, installation of electrical and other wiring underground, removal of existing improvements on the subject site, utilization of an amenity bonus, dedication of any requisite rights-of-way, granting of necessary statutory rights-of-way, easements, and/or covenants, registration of a Housing Covenant and Housing Agreement, submission of a suitable Stormwater Management System, compliance with Groundwater Management guidelines, submission of a geotechnical and groundwater study, execution of an indemnity agreement, submission of a Solid Waste and Recycling Plan, review of on-site loading facilities, provision of car wash stalls and garbage handling/recycling space, provision of facilities for cyclists, design and provision of units adaptable to persons with disabilities, approval of the Ministry of Transportation and Infrastructure, compliance with sound criteria, compliance with guidelines for underground parking for visitors, submission of a detailed Public Art Plan, submission of a Green Building Plan and Energy Benchmarking, submission of a detailed Comprehensive Sign Plan, submission of a Site Disclosure Statement, and deposit of applicable charges.
Chief Administrative Officer’s Comments: I concur with the recommendation of the General Manager Planning and Development.
Executive Summary: A rezoning application has been received to permit the construction of a high density mixed-use development on the subject site within the Lougheed Core Area Master Plan. The proposal includes a high-rise strata residential building, high-rise non-market and market rental residential building, commercial podium with an office component and street-fronting retail, and underground parking. The purpose of this report is to provide Council with information on the proposal and recommend forwarding the rezoning application to a future Public Hearing.
Policy Section: The proposed rezoning application is consistent with various policies and plans adopted by Council, including the Regional Context Statement, Corporate Strategic Plan, Official Community Plan, Lougheed Town Centre Plan, Lougheed Core Area Master Plan, Economic Development Strategy, Social Sustainability Strategy, Environmental Sustainability Strategy, and Climate Action Plan.
Action Framework (2020); Transportation Plan (2021); Home Strategy (2021); and, Rental Use Zoning Policy (2020).

2.0 BACKGROUND

2.1 The subject site is located at 3965 North Road, within the Core Area Master Plan of the Lougheed Town Centre Plan area. The property is currently improved with a gas service station and an older two-storey office commercial building.

2.2 The adopted Lougheed Core Area Master Plan (Rezoning Reference #15-23) is a reconceptualization of a 29.1 hectare (72 acre) area into a vibrant, pedestrian and transit-connected, mixed-use community with diverse housing, employment, service, and recreation opportunities. The Master Plan provides direction related to the general land use, form, massing, subdivision pattern, site servicing, development phasing, and distribution of applicable development densities in the core area. The Master Plan includes eight major development phases for the lands encompassing the Lougheed Mall and select properties to the south, including the subject site. All sites within the Master Plan are designated for high-density mixed-use development based on land uses and densities permitted under the RM5s, C3 and P2 Districts.

2.3 The Master Plan had identified the subject property as a single tower site to accommodate the density associated with the RM5s and C3 Districts. With the adoption of the Final Rental Use Zoning Policy in 2020 to support the development of rental units in the City, the subject rezoning application is required to comply with Stream 2 – Inclusionary Rental, whereby the applicant is.

nature, with a mix of housing types and sizes to accommodate a diverse population.

2.2 The current zoning for the subject site is RM3 Multiple Family Residential District, which allows for medium-density residential development. The proposed zoning is CD Comprehensive Development District, which is based on the RM4s and RM4r Multiple Family Residential Districts and the Metrotown Downtown Plan guidelines. The proposed development plan, entitled "FORMA," has been prepared by Arcadis IBI Group.

2.3 The applicant, Norm Shearing of OpenForm Properties Ltd., is seeking authorization from Council to proceed with the rezoning application. The purpose of the application is to permit the construction of a multiple-family residential development consisting of a 33-storey residential strata apartment building with street-oriented townhomes, as well as a six-storey replacement rental building.

3.0 RECOMMENDATIONS

3.1 It is recommended that a Rezoning Bylaw be prepared and advanced to First Reading and to a Public Hearing at a future date of Council.

3.2 It is recommended that the introduction of a Housing Agreement Bylaw be authorized, contingent upon the granting of Second Reading of the Rezoning Bylaw. The terms of the Housing Agreement Bylaw are outlined in Section 3.2 of the report.

3.3 It is recommended that certain prerequisites be established for the completion of the rezoning, including the submission of a suitable plan of development, the deposit of sufficient funds to cover the costs of necessary services, the installation of underground electrical, telephone, and cable servicing, the undergrounding of existing overhead wiring, the consolidation of the project site into one legal parcel, the utilization of an amenity bonus through a cash in-lieu contribution, the dedication of necessary rights-of-way, the granting of statutory rights-of-way, easements, and/or covenants, the registration of a Housing Agreement and Housing Covenant, the submission of a suitable stormwater management system, the deposit of sufficient funds for its provision, the submission of an undertaking to remove all improvements on the site within 12 months of Final Adoption of the Rezoning Bylaw, compliance with the City's Groundwater Management guidelines, the submission of a Solid Waste and Recycling plan, the review of on-site residential loading facilities, the provision of car wash stalls and adequate garbage handling and recycling space, the provision of facilities for cyclists, the design and provision of units adaptable to persons with disabilities, compliance with sound criteria, compliance with guidelines for underground parking for visitors, the submission of a Public Art Plan, the submission of a Green Building Plan and Energy Benchmarking, and the payment of various charges including Parkland Acquisition Charge, School Site Acquisition Charge, Water Development Cost Charge, Metrotown Public Open Space Charge, GVS & DD Sewerage Charge, and Regional Transportation Development Cost Charge.

3.4 It is recommended that the applicant provide a written undertaking to distribute area plan notification forms and post area plan notification signs on the development site and in the sales office prior to Third Reading or the commencement of marketing for the development, whichever is first.

4.0 CHIEF ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICER'S COMMENTS

The Chief Administrative Officer concurs with the recommendation of the General Manager Planning and Development.

5.0 EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

A rezoning application has been received for the construction of a high-density multiple-family residential development in the Maywood neighbourhood of the Metrotown Downtown Plan area. The proposed development includes a 33-storey residential strata apartment building with street-oriented townhomes and a six-storey replacement rental building. The rezoning application is consistent with various policies and plans adopted by Council. It is recommended that the rezoning application be forwarded to a future Public Hearing.
The Plan calls for spacious lobbies, ground-level amenities, and access to outdoor open space. It specifies high-rise residential buildings with street-oriented low-rise apartment, townhousing, or row-housing components.

The adopted Metrotown Downtown Plan designates the properties for high-density multiple family residential development using the RM4s and RM4r Multiple Family Residential Districts as guidelines. The subject properties are currently zoned RM3 Multiple Family Residential District and have three-storey rental apartment buildings from the 1960s with a total of 83 units. Vehicular access is from the rear lane.

On December 06, 2021, Council received an initial rezoning report proposing to rezone the two subject properties (6470 and 6508 Silver Avenue) in line with the adopted Plan. Council authorized staff to work with the applicant to prepare a suitable plan of development, with a more detailed report to be submitted later.

Meeting: October 16, 2023
File: 16000-20
Council Report to: Mayor & Council
From: General Manager Planning and Development
Subject: Burnaby Housing Authority - Approval to Request Creation of a Municipal Corporation
Recommendations:
1. Approve the formation of the Burnaby Housing Authority as a municipal corporation.
2. Authorize staff to submit a request to obtain the approval of the Inspector of Municipalities to form the Burnaby Housing Authority as a municipal corporation, including the draft Burnaby Housing Authority Corporation Articles of Incorporation and the Burnaby Housing Authority Business Plan.
3. Authorize the General Manager Planning and Development to represent the City on the submission to the Inspector of Municipalities.
4. Direct staff to include planned contributions and financing in the draft 2024-2028 Financial Plan for the Burnaby Housing Authority.
Chief Administrative Officer's Comments: I concur with the recommendations of the General Manager Planning and Development.
Executive Summary: This report seeks Council approval to submit a request to the Inspector of Municipalities to create the Burnaby Housing Authority as a municipal corporation. The establishment of the Burnaby Housing Authority aligns with various City policies and strategies related to housing and development.
Background: Non-market housing in Burnaby is currently delivered through multiple channels, including the City, other levels of government, non-profit organizations, and the private sector. The City has been successful in facilitating new non-market housing, but there is a need for a coordinated program to address immediate housing needs. The Burnaby Housing Authority would serve as a "one-stop shop" for the development, management, and administration of non-market housing.
General Information: The City is required to seek approval from the Inspector of Municipalities to create a municipal corporation. The submission to the Inspector must include a cover letter, certified copy of Council's resolution, and background reports such as the Business Plan and feasibility studies.
corporate registry for the incorporation of the BHA as a separate legal entity. The Articles contain essential details such as the name, purpose, share structure, and directors of the corporation.

Meeting: October 30, 2023
File: 49500 02
REZ#22-24
COUNCIL REPORT
TO: MAYOR & COUNCIL
FROM: GENERAL MANAGER PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT
SUBJECT: REZ #22-24 – 3945 MYRTLE STREET – RESPONSE TO ISSUES RAISED AT SECOND READING
PURPOSE: To provide further information on the issues raised at Second Reading for REZ #22-24.
REFERENCES:
Address: 3945 Myrtle Street
Legal: Lot "B" District Lot 69 Group 1 New Westminster District Plan 17722
Applicant: Tony Russo; 1074649 BC Ltd. 203 – 1312 Ketch Court, Coquitlam, BC V3K 6W1
Current Zoning: M6 Truck Terminal District and R5 Residential District
Proposed Zoning: CD Comprehensive Development District (based upon M1 Manufacturing District and M2 General Industrial District as guidelines and in accordance with the development plan entitles "Self Storage Units 3944 Still Creek Burnaby, BC" prepared by Studio One Architecture Inc.)
RECOMMENDATION:
THAT a copy of this report be sent to the applicant for REZ #22-24; and
THAT Bylaw No. 14591 for REZ #22-24 be advanced to Second Reading.
CHIEF ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICER'S COMMENTS: I concur with the recommendation of the General Manager Planning and Development.
1.0 BACKGROUND
On August 29, 2023 a public hearing was held for REZ #22-24. The purpose of the subject rezoning application is to permit the construction of a five-storey enclosed self-storage facility with two levels of underground parking (see Attachment 1).
At the September 11, 2023 Council Meeting, Council raised questions relating to the provision of jobs through this storage use. Prior to Second Reading, Council asked that a staff report be submitted to respond to the questions raised. Staff spoke to the applicant who has expressed interest in pursuing the existing proposal. This report responds to Council's questions regarding the level of employment being achieved through this rezoning application.
2.0 ISSUES RAISED
2.1 Provision of Jobs
Questions were raised regarding the number of jobs supported by this application. The subject rezoning application is proposed as a self-storage facility business model specifically for small businesses. It follows the model of a self-storage facility that the applicant previously developed, constructed, and managed in Port Coquitlam from 2017-2022. This facility was utilized by residents as well as a wide variety of small and emerging businesses such as clothing companies, electricians, bakeries, IT companies, landscaping companies, and printing companies. These small businesses used this facility to store their inventory, supplies, equipment, and files in the secure and temperature controlled storage units. The facility also worked with logistics companies to store and receive packages on behalf of these small business. Therefore, while this facility only employed 5-6 individuals, it indirectly supported over 200 small businesses. With the clientele of small businesses in mind and the lessons learned from the Port Coquitlam self-storage facility, the applicant sought to provide this opportunity in Burnaby through this rezoning application. This self-storage facility is proposed to have 872 climate-controlled storage units ranging in size, bike lockers for employees, two levels of underground parking, two large industrial sized elevators, and intensive security systems for the broader facility as well as individual units. The fifth floor of the Burnaby self-storage facility is proposed to have a 2,187.2 sq. ft. amenity space that includes a kitchen, a washroom, a lounge area, a coffee bar area, a meeting room, as well as an outdoor amenity area (see Attachment 2). The facility is also located within a 900 m walking distance of the Gilmore SkyTrain Station, providing access for individuals and businesses across Metro Vancouver.
2.2 Self-Storage Use in Industrial Zones
Concerns were raised regarding self-storage uses in industrial zoning districts. The self-storage use is a permitted use for this site as set out in the City of Burnaby's Official Community Plan (1998) and Metro 2050 (2022) land use designations that permit industrial uses.
In the Burnaby Zoning Bylaw, self-storage uses are permitted in industrial zoning districts only. This proposed self-storage facility combines the M1 Manufacturing District and the M2 General Industrial District. This combination of zoning districts allows for a much more intensified use of industrial land by enabling a multi-storey industrial building. This aligns directly with the Metro Vancouver Regional Industrial Lands Strategy (2020) and City of Burnaby's Official Community Plan (1998), which outline the intensification of employment and floor space on redeveloping.

Executive Summary: A rezoning application has been received for the Southgate Neighbourhood. The proposed Master Plan amendment rezoning application (REZ #22-31A) aims to amend the Southgate Master Plan to facilitate future land uses and development in accordance with the City's Rental Use Zoning Policy. The proposed Site Specific rezoning application (REZ #22-31B) aims to permit the construction of a mixed-use development within the Courtyard Neighbourhood of the Southgate Master Plan area. The report recommends bringing forward the Rezoning Bylaws for First Reading and forwarding the rezoning application to future Public Hearings.
Policy Section: The proposed rezoning application is consistent with various policies and plans adopted by Council, including the Regional Context Statement, Corporate Strategic Plan, Official Community Plan, Edmonds Town Centre Plan, Economic Development Strategy, Social Sustainability Strategy, Environmental Sustainability Strategy, Climate Action Framework, Transportation Plan, Home Strategy, and Rental Use Zoning Policy.
Background: On July 20, 2015, Council granted Final Adoption to REZ #14-25, which established a Conceptual Master Plan framework for Southgate. The approved Southgate Master Plan permits a maximum residential density and includes provisions for different housing options.
The document states that there is a total area of 5,883,678 sq.ft. across five neighbourhood areas. A Density Allocation Covenant is in place to regulate the transfer of gross floor area (15%) between these areas.

The Southgate Master Plan was adopted, and on February 19, 2020, the Rental Use Zoning Policy (RUZP) was also adopted to support rental unit development in the City. The RUZP will be implemented through a Master Plan rezoning amendment in connection with this Site Specific Rezoning (SSR) application. Additional density of up to 2.20 for RM5r rental units and up to 1.10 FAR for RM5 density offset is proposed to meet the requirements of the RUZP.

The site area has been reduced from the original application due to redevelopment and construction in certain neighbourhoods. The RM5r and density offset will only be applied to the remaining phases, referred to as the "Amendment Site Area".

Figure 1 shows a map of Southgate's neighbourhood areas and the original site area.

A rezoning application has been received to permit the construction of two mid-rise residential buildings with underground parking. The recommendation is to bring the Rezoning Bylaw forward for First Reading and forward the rezoning application to a future Public Hearing.

The proposed rezoning application is consistent with various policies and plans adopted by Council.
Background:
On June 20, 2022, Council authorized staff to work with Amacon Development Corporation Inc. on the development plans for the Halifax Site and Rosser Site within the Brentwood Town Centre. On August 31, 2022, Council approved a density transfer from the Halifax Site to the Rosser Site. The subject site is currently improved with a residential rental apartment building and is designated for medium-density multiple-family residential development.
Centre Development Plan expects new developments to provide community benefits, sustainable redevelopment, exceptional public realm improvements, high-quality urban design, and superior architectural expression. The applicant has submitted a development plan suitable for presentation to a Public Hearing. The proposed plan includes two six-storey midrise, mixed-tenure rental residential buildings with an internal courtyard, amenity spaces, and underground parking. Vehicular access to the site is proposed from Ridgelawn Drive. The development concept involves demolishing an older rental residential building with 87 dwelling units and replacing it with two buildings totaling 257 rental residential dwelling units. The proposed development offers a modern aesthetic, inclusive design, street-level unit access, shared amenity spaces, and a well-programmed communal courtyard. It includes a range of housing types from studios and one-bedroom units to three-bedroom and den units as well as three-bedroom townhouses. Overall, the proposal demonstrates high-quality urban design and architectural expression in terms of the building's siting, massing, pedestrian orientation, and materiality.

Background: Council authorized staff to work with Amacon Development Corporation Inc. for the preparation of suitable plans of development for the Rosser Site and Halifax Site. A density transfer from the Halifax Site to the Rosser Site was approved by Council.
Rental units will be developed on the subject site (Rosser Site) before the Halifax Site. This allows residents of the Halifax site to temporarily relocate to the Rosser Site until their replacement rental units are ready. The subject site is approximately 4,333 m2 (46,640 sq. ft.) and consists of two properties on Rosser Avenue. The site also includes a City lane that will be closed according to the Brentwood Town Centre Development Plan. Currently, the site has older industrial units and a residential sales centre. The site is designated for medium to high-density mixed-use development, including the possibility of a hotel. The addition of a hotel is supported by staff as it will enhance the community by providing an active destination. The hotel will be located at 2211 Rosser Avenue. Under the 's' zoning category, new developments are expected to provide community benefits, sustainable redevelopment, public art, high-quality urban design, and superior architectural expression. The applicant has submitted a suitable plan of development for a Public Hearing.

4. Approve the sale in principle of City-owned property for inclusion within the subject development site according to the terms outlined in Section 3.9 of the report, and subject to the applicant pursuing the rezoning proposal to completion.

Chief Administrative Officer's Comments: Concur with the recommendation of the General Manager Planning and Development.
Executive Summary: A rezoning application has been received for the construction of a high-density mixed-tenure residential development atop a commercial/retail podium and underground parking. Recommend forwarding the rezoning application to a future Public Hearing.
Policy Section: The proposed rezoning application is consistent with various policies and plans adopted by Council.
Background: The subject site is part of the Buchanan West Master Plan and represents the first property to be brought forward for site-specific rezoning and redevelopment. The plan envisions high-rise mixed-use buildings, a pedestrian connection, and a new local street. The subject site is located on the north side of Lougheed Highway.
The subject site is located on Gilmore Avenue within the Brentwood Town Centre Development Plan area. The site is designated for high-density mixed-use development, utilizing the RM5s and RM5r Multiple Family Residential Districts, and the C3 General Commercial District as guidelines. The site measures approximately 6,016.70 m2 (64,763 sq. ft.) and includes 4141 Lougheed Highway, the City lane to the west, and a small triangular portion of Lougheed Highway. The site currently has an older industrial warehouse building and surface parking. Vehicular access is provided from Gilmore Avenue via a registered easement across a portion of 1934 Gilmore Avenue.

On June 20, 2022, Council received a rezoning report proposing to rezone the site to the CD Comprehensive Development District, utilizing the RM5s and RM5r Multiple Family Residential Districts, C3 General Commercial District, and the Brentwood Town Centre Development Plan as guidelines. The applicant has submitted a plan of development suitable for presentation to a Public Hearing.

The proposed development plan includes two high-rise residential apartment buildings on top of a commercial/retail podium and underground parking. Vehicle access to the site is currently through 1934 Gilmore Avenue, and access to the development is proposed via a temporary street within the easement. Vehicular access will also be provided from and to the east once 4199 Lougheed Highway is redeveloped. Pedestrian access is provided from both Lougheed Highway and the future east-west street along the northern portion of the site. The development will be constructed in a single phase.

The development concept involves demolishing the existing warehouse and surface parking and constructing a 62-storey residential strata building (Building A) in the northeast corner of the lot, and a 54-storey residential market and non-market rental building (Building B) in the southwest corner of the lot. Both buildings sit atop a 10-storey commercial podium, which includes a hotel with supporting amenities and ground-oriented retail units. The commercial podium allows for flexibility in occupancy, allowing the floor space to be utilized for offices or other employment generating uses as permitted within the C3 District.

Executive Summary: A rezoning application has been received for the construction of mixed-use development above underground parking. The proposal includes two six-storey mixed-use buildings with commercial uses at grade and 85 residential units above. The purpose of this report is to provide information on the proposal and recommend bringing the Rezoning Bylaw forward for First Reading and a future Public Hearing.
Policy Section: The proposed rezoning application is consistent with various policies and plans adopted by Council.
Background: The subject development site is located along Kingsway and Grimmer Street, designated for medium density mixed-use development in the Royal Oak Community Plan. The applicant has elected to proceed with the rezoning proposal despite potential future updates to the Community Plan. Staff recommend proceeding with the rezoning application concurrent with the Community Plan update.
The subject rezoning proposal aligns with the medium density mixed use designation in the Royal Oak Community Plan. The applicant has submitted a development plan for a Public Hearing. The proposal includes two six-storey mixed-use buildings with commercial uses on the ground floor and 85 residential units above (75 strata units and ten non-market rental units). There will be underground parking accessed from an interior courtyard area on Grimmer Street. A public walkway will be provided from Kingsway to Grimmer Street. The maximum potential density for the site is 3.025 FAR, consisting of 2.2 FAR C9 density and 0.825 FAR C9 density offset. The proposed total density for the site is also 3.025 FAR.

Executive Summary: Rezoning application received for a high density mixed-use development in the Lougheed Core Area Master Plan. Proposal includes high-rise residential buildings, commercial podium, and underground parking. Recommend forwarding the application to a future Public Hearing.
Policy Section: Proposed rezoning application consistent with various policies and plans adopted by Council.
Action Framework (2020), Transportation Plan (2021), Home Strategy (2021), and Rental Use Zoning Policy (2020) are the documents being cleaned and formatted.

The subject site is located at 3965 North Road, within the Core Area Master Plan of the Lougheed Town Centre Plan area. The property currently has a gas service station and an older two-storey office commercial building.

The adopted Lougheed Core Area Master Plan (Rezoning Reference #15-23) reconceptualizes a 29.1 hectare (72 acre) area into a vibrant, pedestrian and transit-connected, mixed-use community. The Master Plan provides direction for land use, form, massing, subdivision pattern, site servicing, development phasing, and distribution of development densities in the core area. It includes eight major development phases for the lands encompassing the Lougheed Mall and select properties to the south, including the subject site. All sites within the Master Plan are designated for high-density mixed-use development based on land uses and densities permitted under the RM5s, C3, and P2 Districts.

The Master Plan identified the subject property as a single tower site to accommodate the density associated with the RM5s and C3 Districts. With the adoption of the Final Rental Use Zoning Policy in 2020, the subject rezoning application is required to comply with Stream 2 – Inclusionary Rental.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
A rezoning application has been received in order to permit the construction of two mid-rise residential apartment buildings atop live-work units and underground parking in accordance with Phase 1 of the Burnaby Lake Heights Master Plan (Rezoning Reference #22-15).
The purpose of this report is to provide Council with information on the proposal and to recommend that the amended Rezoning Bylaw be brought forward for Second Reading and the rezoning application be forwarded to a future Public Hearing.
1.0 POLICY SECTION
The proposed rezoning application is consistent with the following policies and plans adopted by Council:
• Regional Context Statement (2013);
• Corporate
Strategic Plan (2022); Official Community Plan (1998); Bainbridge Urban Village Community Plan (2022); Economic Development Strategy (2007); Social Sustainability Strategy (2011); Environmental Sustainability Strategy (2016); Climate Action Framework (2020); Transportation Plan (2021); Home Strategy (2021); and, Rental Use Zoning Policy (2020).

2.0 BACKGROUND
2.1 This report supersedes the prior Public Hearing report for the subject site, which was advanced to Council on September 25, 2023. This revised report clarifies that the proposed non-market rental for the subject site will utilize RM5r District density. No other changes to the form of development, use, or density outlined in the prior Public Hearing report result from this clarification.
2.2 On June 05, 2023 Council granted Second Reading to Rezoning Reference #22-15 for the Burnaby Lake Heights Master Plan, which established a Conceptual Master Plan framework and companion Design Guidelines for the 7000 Lougheed Highway site. The intent of the Master Rezoning is to guide site specific rezoning applications for a multi-phased residential and commercial mixed use development on the approximately 14 acre site. The subject site comprises phase 1 of the Master Plan, which includes two mid-rise residential apartment buildings, the western portions of the Esplanade (a signature pedestrian boulevard) and the Serpentine (an east-west greenway with passive and active programming), a significant portion of the Forest Walk (a regenerated forest corridor with special activity nodes), and the new north-south street linking Lougheed Highway through to Greenwood Street.
2.2 The Phase 1 site is located on the south side of Lougheed Highway approximately midway between Bainbridge Avenue and Sperling Avenue, within the Council adopted Bainbridge Urban Village Community Plan. The Bainbridge Plan designates the site for high-density mixed-use development, utilizing the RM5uv-a Multiple Family Residential District, RM5r Multiple Family Residential.

Executive Summary: Rezoning application received for construction of two high-rise mixed tenure residential apartment buildings atop commercial podium and underground parking in accordance with Brentwood West Master Plan. Recommend forwarding rezoning application to future Public Hearing.
Policy Section: Proposed rezoning application consistent with various policies and plans adopted by Council.
Background: Council previously granted Final Adoption to Rezoning Reference #19-19 for Brentwood West Conceptual Master Plan. Subject site comprises phases 1 and 2 of Master Plan, aiming for high-density mixed-use development and provision of housing options, employment opportunities, and public open space provisions.
The subject site is located at the southwest corner of Willingdon Avenue and Halifax Street, within the Council adopted Brentwood Town Centre Development Plan. It is designated for high-density mixed-use development, utilizing the RM5s, RM5r Multiple Family Residential Districts, C3 General Commercial District, and the Brentwood Town Centre Development Plan as guidelines. The site is approximately 7090.08 m2 (76,317 sq. ft.) in size and is comprised of three individual parcels and a portion of Buchanan Street, which is identified for closure under the Brentwood Town Centre Development Plan. Two of the parcels (4430 Halifax Street and 1801 Willingdon Avenue) are currently improved with older commercial buildings, and the remaining parcel at 4488 Halifax Street is vacant.

On 2023 February 06, Council received an initial rezoning report proposing to rezone the subject development site from its prevailing CD Comprehensive Development District to an amended CD Comprehensive Development District utilizing the RM5s Multiple Family Residential District, RM5r Multiple Family Residential District, C3 General Commercial District, and the Brentwood Town Centre Development Plan as guidelines. The applicant has now submitted a plan of development suitable for presentation to a Public Hearing.

The proposed development plan for the subject site is for two high-rise residential apartment buildings atop a non-market residential rental and commercial/retail podium with underground parking. The development is anticipated to be constructed over two main phases, with Phase 1 encompassing the western half of the site and Phase 2 the eastern half. However, the applicant has the flexibility and discretion to proceed with build out of both phases concurrently, should they decide to do so.

Phase 1 of the development plan comprises a single 60 storey residential strata apartment building, a 9 storey non-market rental podium with townhouses fronting Buchanan Street, and locally scaled commercial retail units fronting Halifax Street. Phase 1 also includes a shared surface plaza accessed from Buchanan Street to accommodate loading, as well as a pedestrianized commercial arcade connecting Halifax Street through to Buchanan Street.

Phase 2 of the development plan comprises a single 43 storey mixed-use tower, with market rental uses located on the upper floors, office uses in the podium, and locally scaled commercial retail units at the base of the building fronting all bounding streets and public spaces. As identified in the Brentwood Town Centre Development Plan and the adopted Brentwood West Conceptual Master Plan, Phase 2 also includes the closure of a portion of Buchanan Street for consolidation with the development site to enable the realization of a new public square.

A rezoning application has been received for the construction of a multiple family residential development as part of the Willingdon Lands Urban Village Master Plan. The development consists of three buildings: a six-storey non-market rental building, a 14-storey market rental and non-market rental building, and a 20-storey leasehold strata building with street-oriented townhomes. The recommendation is to forward the rezoning application to a future Public Hearing.
Policy Section:
The proposed rezoning application is consistent with various policies and plans adopted by Council, including the Corporate Strategic Plan, Regional Context Statement, Official Community Plan, Economic Development Strategy, Social Sustainability Strategy, Environmental Sustainability Strategy, Transportation Plan, and HOME: Housing and Homelessness Strategy.
Background:
The redevelopment of the Willingdon Lands site as an Urban Village and Business Centre has been facilitated through Official Community Plan amendments. The conceptual Master Plan envisions a mixed-use urban village community. The Phase 1 rezoning application was received and will be considered for final reading in the coming months.
In accordance with its Urban Village designation under the Official Community Plan and Willingdon Lands Master Plan, Council authorized staff to work with the applicant on a suitable plan of development. The applicant has now submitted a plan of development for Phase 1, consisting of three multiple family residential buildings. The proposed development includes a six-storey non-market rental building, a 20-storey leasehold strata building, and a 14-storey rental building. Vehicular access is provided through an internal road with two underground parkades and a central servicing courtyard.

Chief Administrative Officer's Comments: Concurs with General Manager Planning and Development's recommendation
Executive Summary:
- Proposed rezoning to establish development guidelines for non-market rental housing
Policy Section:
- Consistent with various policies and plans adopted by Council
Background:
- City-owned site in Newcombe Community Plan area
- Designated for low density multiple-family development
- Funding allocated for affordable rental units
- BC Housing interested in collaborating for additional units
- Development guidelines prepared for Public Hearing
General Information:
- Site designated for low density multiple-family development
- Proposed development guidelines indicate Comprehensive Development District zoning and maximum height of five-storeys
- Maximum potential density up to 1.4 FAR
- City will provide necessary services and utilities
- Statutory right-of-way required for off-site servicing and infrastructure installation
- Section 219 Covenant required for construction commencement and satisfaction of various requirements

Staff Report
Origin: Rav Bains has applied to the City of Richmond for permission to rezone 8420 Heather Street from the "Single Detached (RS1/B)" zone to the "Single Detached (RS2/A)" zone, to permit the property to be subdivided into two equal-sized single family lots with secondary suites and vehicle access from Heather Street (Attachment 1). The proposed subdivision plan is shown in Attachment 2.
Findings of Fact: A Development Application Data Sheet providing details about the development proposal is provided in Attachment 3.
Subject Site Existing Housing Profile: There is an existing single-family home on the property, which would be demolished. No existing secondary suites are present. The existing single-family home is currently renter occupied.
Surrounding Development: Development immediately surrounding the subject site is as follows: To the North: A single-family dwelling on a lot zoned "Single Detached (RS1/A)" fronting Heather Street. To the South: A single-family dwelling on a lot zoned "Single Detached (RS1/B)" fronting Heather Street. To the East: A townhouse complex on a lot zoned "Low Density Townhouses (RTL1)", with vehicle access from Dayton Avenue. To the West: Two (2) single-family dwellings on lots zoned "Single Detached (RS1/K)" fronting Heather Street.
Related Policies & Studies: Official Community Plan/Broadmoor Planning Area - Ash Street Sub Area Plan: The subject property is designated as "Neighbourhood Residential" in the Official Community Plan (OCP) and is located in the Broadmoor Planning Area and is designated for "Low Density Residential" in the Broadmoor Area - Ash Street Sub-Area Plan (Attachment 4). The proposed rezoning and subdivision is consistent with this designation.
PLN - 28
December 15, 2022
- 3 -
RZ 21-938262
7060487
Floodplain Management Implementation Strategy: The proposed redevelopment must meet the requirements of the Richmond Flood Plain Designation and Protection Bylaw 8204. Registration of a flood indemnity covenant on Title is required prior to final adoption of the rezoning bylaw.
Public Consultation: A rezoning sign has been installed on the subject property. Staff have not received any comments from the public about the rezoning application in response to the placement of the rezoning sign on the property. Should the Planning Committee endorse this application and Council grant first reading to the rezoning bylaw, the bylaw will be forwarded to a Public Hearing, where any area resident or interested party will have an opportunity to comment. Public notification for the Public Hearing will be provided as per the Local Government Act and the City's Zoning Bylaw 8500.
Analysis: This redevelopment proposes to rezone and subdivide an existing single-family lot into two new single-family lots approximately 10 m wide with vehicular access from Heather Street. This rezoning and subdivision is consistent with the lot fabric, lot width and vehicular access of lots to the north along Heather Street and with the Ash Street Sub-Area Plan.
Existing Legal Encumbrances: There is an existing 1.5 m Statutory Right-Of-Way (SRW) across the entire rear (east) property line for the sanitary sewer, which will not be impacted by this development proposal. The applicant is aware that encroachment into the SRW is not permitted.
Transportation and Site Access: Vehicle access is proposed to be provided from Heather Street via separate driveway crossings to each new lot. Parking will be provided in accordance with the Zoning Bylaw.
Site Servicing and Frontage Improvements: At the subdivision stage, the applicant is required pay, in keeping with the Subdivision and Development Bylaw No. 8751, a $29,200.00 cash-in-lieu contribution for the design and construction of frontage upgrades as set out in Attachment 5. The applicant is also required to pay, at subdivision stage, the costs associated with the completion of the site servicing through a City Work Order as described in Attachment 5. In addition, at subdivision stage, the applicant is required to pay the current year's taxes, Development Cost Charges (City and GVS & TransLink), School Site Acquisition Charges and Address Assignment Fees.

Report to Planning Committee
Date: December 15, 2022
From: Wayne Craig, Director, Development
File: RZ 21-940333
Re: Application by Gurjit Pooni for Rezoning at 8691 Heather Street

Staff Recommendation: Introduce and give first reading to Richmond Zoning Bylaw 8500, Amendment Bylaw 10416, for the rezoning of 8691 Heather Street from "Single Detached (RS1/B)" zone to "Single Detached (RS2/K)" zone.

REPORT CONCURRENCE: Affordable Housing; CONCURRENCE OF DFWLQJ GENERAL MANAGER PLN - 7

Gurjit Pooni has applied to rezone 8691 Heather Street to permit the property to be subdivided into two single-family lots. One lot will be accessed from Heather Street and the other from Dolphin Avenue. See Attachment 1 for a map and aerial photograph of the subject site. The proposed subdivision is provided in Attachment 2.

Findings of Fact: See Attachment 3 for a Development Application Data Sheet.

Subject Site Existing Housing Profile: There is an existing tenant-occupied single-family dwelling on the subject property with vehicular access from Heather Street. The dwelling will be demolished. There are no existing secondary suites in the dwelling.

Surrounding Development:
- North: Single-family dwelling on a property zoned "Single Detached (RS1/A)".
- South: Single-family dwellings on properties zoned "Single Detached (RS1/B)" across Dolphin Avenue.
- East: Single-family dwellings on properties zoned "Single Detached (RS1/B)" across Heather Street.
- West: Single-family dwelling on a property zoned "Single Detached (RS1/B)".

Related Policies & Studies: The subject property is designated as "Neighbourhood Residential" in the Official Community Plan (OCP) and is located in the Broadmoor Planning Area. It is designated for "Low Density Residential" in the Broadmoor Area - Ash Street Sub-Area Plan (Attachment 4).

Floodplain Management Implementation Strategy: The proposed redevelopment must meet the requirements of the Richmond Flood Plain Designation and Protection Bylaw 8204. Registration of a flood indemnity covenant on Title is required prior to final adoption of the rezoning bylaw.

Public Consultation: No public comments have been received regarding the rezoning application.

Analysis: The proposed redevelopment will rezone and subdivide the existing single-family lot into two new single-family lots. Lot A will have access from Dolphin Avenue and Lot B (the corner lot) will have access from Heather Street. This is consistent with the lot fabric and vehicular access of neighboring lots. The applicant will be required to provide a landscape plan and register a restrictive covenant on Title to ensure the development's design is consistent with approved plans.

Existing Legal Encumbrances: None.

Transportation and Site Access: The subject site currently has vehicular access from Heather Street. Vehicle access to proposed Lot A will be from Dolphin Avenue and vehicle access to proposed Lot B will be from Heather Street. Sidewalks and landscaped boulevards are to be installed along both streets as part of a Servicing Agreement.

Staff Recommendation:
1. That Official Community Plan Amendment Bylaw 10213 be introduced and given first reading, including amending the land use designation of 7840 River Road from "Park" to "Commercial" and amending the land use designation of 7711 River Road and a portion of 7851 River Road from "Commercial" to "Park". Also, amending infrastructure policies to clarify the City's intent regarding dike improvements and amending the land use designations in various maps to relocate park, road, pedestrian linkages, and commercial uses in the vicinity of 7840 River Road, 7711 River Road, and a portion of 7851 River Road.
2. That Bylaw 10213 is consistent with the City's Financial Plan and Capital Program, as well as the Greater Vancouver Regional District Solid Waste and Liquid Waste Management Plans.
3. That Bylaw 10213 does not require further consultation.
4. That Richmond Zoning Bylaw 8500, Amendment Bylaw 10212 be introduced and given first reading, creating the "High Rise Riverfront Commercial (ZC49) – Aberdeen Village (City Centre)" zone and rezoning 7780, 7800, 7804, 7820, and 7840 River Road from "Auto-Oriented Commercial (CA)" to "High Rise Riverfront Commercial (ZC49) – Aberdeen Village (City Centre)".

Wayne Craig, Director, Development

REPORT CONCURRENCE
Arts, Culture & Heritage; Community Social Development; Engineering; Law; Parks Services; Policy Planning; Real Estate Services; Community Services Planning & Projects; Sustainability & District Energy; Transportation

Staff Report
Origin: Urban Solutions Architecture Ltd., on behalf of the property owner, 1089260 B C Ltd. (CIBT Education Group and Global Education City Holdings Inc.), has applied to the City of Richmond for permission to rezone lands at 7780, 7800, 7804, 7820, and 7840 River Road from "Auto-Oriented Commercial (CA)" to "High Rise Riverfront Commercial (ZC49) – Aberdeen Village (City Centre)" to construct a high density commercial development along the Fraser River's Middle Arm. The development includes an 11-storey hotel, an 8-storey office building, retail and restaurant uses at grade, and underground parking. The total floor area is approximately 21,625 m² (232,769 ft²) comprising of hotel, retail/restaurant, and office space. The design and construction will meet Step 2 of the BC Energy Step Code, and there will be voluntary developer contributions towards public art and community amenities. Off-site works will be undertaken for dike upgrades and utility and road upgrades, as well as public realm improvements. Official Community Plan and City Centre Area Plan amendments are proposed to clarify the City's intent regarding dike improvements and to relocate park, road, pedestrian linkage, and commercial land use designations.

Findings of Fact:
- There are no existing residential dwellings on the subject site.

REPORT CONCURRENCE
PH - 92
February 6, 2023

Staff Report
Origin: TU 23-009170
DA Architects & Planners have applied to the City of Richmond for an extension to an existing Temporary Commercial Use Permit (TCUP) for the property at 8991 Charles Street. This permit would allow for the limited storage of rental vehicles with no associated buildings and no public access. The subject site is zoned "Light Industrial (IL)" and the TCUP would permit the outdoor storage of rental vehicles associated with the Routes Car Rental business at 9231 Beckwith Road. The original TCUP (TU 20-891050) was issued on March 16, 2020 for a three-year term expiring on March 16, 2023. The proposed TCUP extension would allow Routes Car Rental to continue storing rental vehicles on the subject site with no public access for up to three years from the date of issuance. There are no proposed changes to the layout or access permitted by the existing TCUP.

Findings of Fact:
There are no existing buildings or structures on the subject property. The surrounding development includes the Bridgeport Canada Line Station and a bus loop to the north, office and warehouse buildings with parking and unoccupied lots to the south, a temporary modular housing development to the east, and the Bridgeport Canada Line Station and bus loop to the west.

Existing Legal Encumbrances:
Two Statutory Right-of-Ways (SRWs) are registered on Title but do not impact the proposed use.

Related Policies & Studies:
The Official Community Plan (OCP) land use designation for the subject site is "Commercial" and the Bridgeport Sub-Area Plan designation is "Urban Centre TS (45m)". The proposed TCUP is consistent with these designations. The subject site is zoned "Light Industrial (IL)" which allows for a range of general industrial and commercial uses. The proposed TCUP would limit the use to the storage of rental vehicles with restricted access to operators only.

Local Government Act:
Temporary Commercial Use Permits are valid for three years from the date of issuance. An application for extension to the permit may be made and issued by Council for up to three additional years. After this one-time extension, a new TCUP application would be required.

Public Consultation:
No comments have been received from the public regarding the TCUP application.
